page.title: 04Bovingdon Hall - Ecology
page.content: The ancient woodland, dating back possibly to the Ice Age,is designated as an{Site of Special Scientific {Interest.}It consists mainly of{oak, {lime, hornbeam and hazel.}In newly coppiced areas{primroses, early purple {orchids, wood anemones}and{bugle}are increasing. The rare{Bardield oxslip and{birds nest orchid}have been found. There is a{wild service tree. {Purple hairstreak}and{white {admiral}butterflies have been recorded.{Woodcock}have nested in the coppice regrowth.{Kestrels}breed in conserved derelict buildings. There is a{heronry}in{Maids Wood. Altogether the estate supports 55 species of breeding birds,{197 herbs and{flowering plants}and at least{16 {different butterflies.}New ponds and field corner plantings are helping to increase wildlife.
